It annoys me how blatantly stupid human questions can get. Not always in terms of what is asked, but in terms of what is not asked. "Why do women have orgasms?" The problem here is that the assumption is that a male orgasm has to feel pleasurable in order for us to procreate. So the question should be: "Why does sex feel pleasurable?" And now the question is a lot easier to answer. In this talk, Sapolsky is talking about arousal increases vaginal secretion which helps sperm reach the egg, which greatly increases the likelihood of procreation. But so does sperm. It also leaves the question "Why do female orgasms increase the vaginal secretion that increases the likelihood of reproduction?" The male secretes his stuff, and the female secrete hers. The combination will often produce an offspring. Neither of these rely on it feeling good. The professor dismisses the question about why men have orgasms by saying sperm is way more voluminous with orgasm, but that presupposes that orgasms have to exist for the sperm to be voluminous. This is plainly wrong. This is not a biological necessity at all. It happens to be a fact in humans, but it shouldn't be so easily dismissed. The angler fish male melts into the female, and his body excretes sperm. The orgasm isn't necessary to increase sperm, in general. It just happens to be the case in humans. So why is that?  To make it clear what other options there are: people already want to have babies. They dream about having babies and kids, and romanticize this idea. This is a pure reproductive instinct. That in itself would be enough even if sex hurt. I mean, giving birth hurts like hell, and people still go through it because they want babies. Not because sex is so amazing that it's worth getting split in half. People do it despite this knowledge. They even select for natural birth. There are many species that die horrifically after reproducing, yet they still do it. I would even bet my life that if men's heads exploded if they ever had sex, we'd still do it. And we would sacrifice everything to do it. Just like every other species.  Another option that we for the most part don't experience, but could've been a strong motivating factor, is pain. We avoid injury because it hurts. What if not having sex hurt? And sometimes it actually does. Men's testicles hurt if we do not orgasm often enough. If it hurt ten times worse for everyone, we'd definitely have sex just to soothe the pain. On top of all of this, even with all kinds of sexual replacements (sex toys) people still long for a sexual partner. So pleasure itself doesn't really have such a central part as people think. Obviously, it's a very important factor, but reducing sexual motivation to this is not very intelligent.  That's why "Why do women have orgasms?" is a very stupid question, because it forgets almost everything else. If we combine all of the above, we get a much clearer picture. It hurts not to ejaculate; people have an instinctual desire to have children despite all painful downsides and risks of death; people still seek sexual companionship even when sexual pleasure through toys is available; and on top of all that, orgasms motivate sexual reproduction; fluid secretions from either sex significantly increases the chances of reproduction. Women can band together and fight off men despite the dimorphism (as history tells us they have done before), but them being willing is much more productive. We don't have one factor that motivates reproduction, we have many. And each factor increases the likelihood of reproduction. Orgasms are just one of them.

A philosophical question about the transgender issue is whether the sense of self should be associated with the isolated brain or the whole body including the brain. If we are our only brains, then yes, the body is wrong in the case of transgender individuals. But if our sense of self includes not just our brains but our bodies as well, then we should ask the question as to whether it is the brain that is problematic and that rather than a brain with the wrong body it is the body with an unsynchronized brain. I don't think there is a strong case to be made to say that we are only our brains because the whole "wrong body" idea in itself rests on the idea that we highly identify with our bodies and thus must undergo transition to "make it right".

I think when it comes to humans, and how the brain deals with polygamy/polyamory vastly changes between people. Some people are entirely monogamous, whereas others are entirely poly.
